title: Jimmy Carter hospitalized after second fall in month
text:
Oct. 22 (UPI) — Former President Jimmy Carter was hospitalized Monday in Georgia after his second fall this month, this time suffering a pelvic fracture.

The Carter Center said Tuesday that the president fell at his home in Plains, Ga., and was transported to Phoebe Sumter Medical Center for observation and treatment. The center said the pelvic fracture was minor.

“He is in good spirits and is looking forward to recovering at home,” the center said in a statement.

Carter, 95, fell at his home Oct. 6 and needed 14 stitches above his brow.

“I got up this morning at home in Plains, getting ready to go to church, ’cause right after that we have a family reunion, and then we were coming to Nashville,” Carter told a Habitat for Humanity audience in Tennessee the next day. “And I fell down and hit my forehead on a sharp edge, and had to go to the hospital.”

Carter, the longest-living president in U.S. history, underwent brain cancer treatment in 2017 and had surgery to repair a broken hip in May after suffering another fall at his home while getting ready to go turkey hunting.

The 39th president of the United States beat incumbent Gerald Ford in the 1976 election for president and lost to Ronald Reagan in 1980 after serving one term.
